(Translated by Google) 0 stars! My mother was a patient there after a stroke in November 2020. Medical care was unfortunately a complete failure. Only once did the doctor call me on his own initiative: when my mother suddenly felt considerably worse and he wanted my permission to have her admitted to hospital as an emergency. He suspected the cause of the bad condition was possible night cramps and thought about additional medication for treatment (more medication ...). Later I found out from the hospital's emergency room: the cause was a greatly reduced sodium level in the blood. Any family doctor with a small laboratory can find this out, the rehabilitation clinic was already overwhelmed here. In my opinion, the blood values should have been checked continuously to prevent such a sharp drop. My mother died in the hospital three days later.

I had the feeling that the doctor and nursing staff came in handy when the second Corona wave came in, so they were able to prevent visits and thus evade any control by relatives.
With all due understanding for all the work on a ward: that one day my mother was accidentally put in the wrong patient bed and that this is only noticed because the nurse could not find the phone when I called, it doesn't work at all.

As I brought laundry over, I saw patients in wheelchairs sitting next to the entrance in a winter garden and relatives standing outside in front of it. My telephone request as to whether it would be possible to bring my mother in the wheelchair to the winter garden on another day with advance notice was refused by the nurse with the hint: "Then everyone wants that" ... it would have been the last chance to see my mother at least one more time before she died ... just sad.

The administration didn't work any better either. I have been sent contracts for treatment and laundry care. Some time later I was reminded of the laundry care contract, which I had long since sent. In the end, it turned out that not a single item of laundry was washed. After my mother died, I picked up bags of dirty laundry.

I deeply regret sending my grandma to this hospital and have very bad suspicions.

The short version:

My grandmother suffered from severe diarrhea for the second day. Since my mother and I feared that she might become dehydrated, we called the ambulance that evening, even though my grandmother expressly did not want this and the hospital has the worst reputation ever! One day later in the afternoon it was only possible to speak to the doctor. They said they could handle it.

The impression we got in my grandma's room was very bad. The nurses were very very rude and didn't seem to be doing anything. Medical records were lying around openly and were mixed up. My grandma's bag was not unpacked, it was not washed, she was warm and she seemed to be in pain or shortness of breath. Her condition had HAD HAD ENORMOUSLY! She was supposed to be given an IV and it obviously didn't seem to have happened. The container was full in the room. Another thing we noticed: As a widow, she had two rings on her finger. During our visit only one more !!!!!! A needle was half hanging on my arm and my grandma seemed very weak by then. We left with an extremely bad, oppressive feeling and wanted to have taken her with us. However, an internal blockage should still be drained and so we left the hospital ... This morning we got the call that my grandma had died early in the morning. The call came 5 hours after her death because the doctor on duty did not have the phone number. In the afternoon we drove to the hospital. The doctor on the night shift was off. Clear! And there were no further details from the staff on duty. Nothing. We were sent across the hospital to the pathology department because we had asked to see my grandma again and to be able to say goodbye, which one actually wants to do much earlier. There we were treated very unfriendly and without any compassion. This is all very sad and I suspect that something is wrong there. We have not received a death certificate or an exact report on how the patient was found this morning and when / how she passed away. Heart failure is given as the cause. Clear! Everyone knows that "dehydration" leads either to poisoning or to cardiovascular breakdown / heart failure. Their kidney function was already limited anyway. Since she had diarrhea, took medication (which she didn't even get a day because the nurses didn't look into her pocket) and it seemed like she hadn't eaten anything and had at most had a sip, that of course led to death. Then, to put it bluntly, she could have stayed at home and died, as she wished. After her death, however, they looked into her pocket. Because she was wearing her own nightgown. Before one from the hospital. One could, but did not want to help her. Too old. Too useless. Everything fits! For me the matter is clear and unambiguous and it is time that the public heard about it through the press and thus lives are saved !!!
